awd_titl_txt: Laser mass spectrometer microscopy for analysis of cultural heritage objects
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry and Office of Multidisciplinary Activities, a new collaborative project between Professor de Vries and his group at the University of California-Santa Barbara (UCSB) and researchers at the Getty Conservation Institute (GCI) in Los Angeles will develop a new technique capable of unambiguously identifying organic components in cultural heritage objects. The new method is based on a specialized form of laser mass spectrometry, combined with microscopy in a unique instrument. This approach will have the spatial resolution necessary to isolate small quantities of organic material in discrete layers of tiny mounted samples from paintings (called cross sections), and the sensitivity to provide molecularly specific identification of materials present in very low concentrations. The unambiguous identification of artists' materials at a molecular and microstructural level can elucidate historic geological or biological material sources, manufacturing processes and trade routes. An understanding of works of art additionally assists conservators and curators develop the storage and exhibition protocols necessary to protect and preserve works of art, and assists art historians in their investigations into the relationships between an object, the artist, and the historical and cultural environments in which it was created. The R2PI-uMS technique developed in this work is also expected to enhance scientific research in a number of diverse fields other than art conservation, ranging from organic surface analysis in the electronics industry, to analysis/testing in the modern paint industry, to the study of spatial distributions of metabolites in cells in botanical or biological studies. 

The graduate students that are involved in the project will have the unique opportunity of working in both academic and cultural heritage research environments, helping to foster the next generation of scientists engaged in cultural heritage science. In addition to training graduate students, the researchers will involve undergraduate and high school students in the framework of UCSB sponsored outreach programs to minority students and high schools and the Getty's Graduate Intern and Multicultural Undergraduate Internship programs. In an additional collaboration, students from Jackson State University, a historically black college, will also participate in the project.  By involving such a diverse group of researchers, the PIs will work to increase participation of minority students in STEM fields.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported a new collaborative project between the University of California Santa Barbara (UCSB) and the Getty Conservation Institute (GCI) which has developed an analytical laser mass spectrometric technique capable of unambiguously identifying organic components in cultural heritage objects. The technique is compatible with the miniscule samples typically available from works of art, has the spatial resolution necessary to isolate small quantities of organic material present in such samples, and sufficient sensitivity to provide molecularly specific identification of material classes that are difficult to identify using currently available techniques, thus filling a critical gap in the analysis of cultural heritage materials.

 The analysis of cultural heritage materials presents a number of specific obstacles, all of which impose limitations on the range of applicable analytical techniques: limited numbers of samples, extremely small sample size, complexity of overall sample structure, the importance of maintaining spatial integrity, and, most importantly, the preciousness of the samples, which dictates that noninvasive or minimally invasive techniques be employed. In recent years, instrument developers have made great strides in making the analysis of, in particular, inorganic materials more portable, less invasive, and more sensitive, and therefore more applicable to the analysis of works of cultural heritage. However, there remains a critical need for the development of complementary techniques for organic materials that can provide spatially resolved, molecularly specific, and unambiguous identification of cultural heritage materials.

This work is demonstrated a specialized form of micro sampling and laser mass spectrometry, combining the precision of atomic force microscopy with the selectivity of jet-cooled resonant two photon ionization (R2PI) laser spectroscopy and the sensitivity of mass spectrometry to produce a powerful hybrid approach with unique properties for identifying organic molecules with unprecedented spatial resolution and sensitivity.

Specifically, the project (1) developed and demonstrated a novel way to obtain samples from sub-micron areas in painting cross sections, using proximity sampling in a atomic force microscope? (2) developed a catalogue of R2PI spectra of tracer compounds, characteristic of ancient organic pigments? (3) demonstrated R2PI mass spectrometry for the analysis of beverage residues in ancient Maya pottery; (4) studied the response to light radiation of anthraquinone colorants, obtaining new insights in photochemical degradation mechanisms of madder lake based pigments; (5) promoted the use of these techniques and fostered scientists in the cultural heritage sector. 

 Broader impacts:

 In addition to the cultural importance of this type of science, this project stimulated close interdisciplinary collaboration between two very different scientific communities, bringing together prominent cultural heritage scientists and physical chemists. Students were exposed to this unique cross fertilizing scientific culture, which will benefit their careers moving forward. Four graduate students were involved in the research leading to two Ph.D. theses so far and a third one well under way. They presented the work at both domestic and international conferences. Eight undergraduate students participated and presented their work at symposia, including participants of the CAMP program (The California Alliance for Minority Participation), participants of the RISE program (Research Internships in Science and Engineering), and students from Jackson State University, a HBCU institution with which we actively collaborate.
